title.value: Global signal topography in the human brain differs systematically across the lifespan
title.justification: Title extracted directly from the research paper.
title.quote: Global signal topography in the human brain differs systematically across the lifespan

extractions.description: This study investigates how global signal topography in the human brain changes across different ages, utilizing a large sample of resting-state fMRI data. The findings indicate that global signal regression, commonly used for data denoising, affects functional connectivity differently based on age, which has crucial implications for lifespan network neuroscience.

type.justification: The paper presents experimental findings based on data analysis and observations from fMRI scans.
type.quote: Using a large cross-sectional sample (601 subjects; 6-86 years old; 10 minute resting-state fMRI scan) of publicly available data (NKI-enhanced; Figure 1), we demonstrate distinct linear and quadratic associations between global signal topography and age for the first time.

name.justification: The study involves the analysis of brain imaging data to understand neural signal changes across the lifespan.
name.quote: These findings have critical implications for lifespan network neuroscience investigations, given that a widely-used data denoising step differentially impacts brain connectivity effects in different age cohorts.

name.justification: The study uses fMRI data to investigate global signal topography and its implications.
name.quote: One of the biggest challenges in neuroscience is separating signal from noise (1). In functional neuroimaging generally, and in human connectomics investigations utilizing resting state functional MRI (fMRI) specifically, this challenge has been met with the development of processing pipelines that mitigate artifacts known to obscure the underlying neural signal (2).

name.justification: The focus of the study is to understand how global signal and functional connectivity change from childhood to old age.
name.quote: Thus, understanding the impact of global signal regression is important for interpreting both past and future studies focusing on age or lifespan FC associations.

name.justification: The paper discusses the relationship between global signal topography and individual differences in cognition and behavior.
name.quote: We have also shown that global signal topography, or the association between each voxelâ€™s time series and the global signal, contains information related to trait-level cognition and behavior.

name.justification: The research used the NKI-enhanced dataset for its analysis.
name.quote: Using a large cross-sectional sample (601 subjects; 6-86 years old; 10 minute resting-state fMRI scan) of publicly available data (NKI-enhanced; Figure 1), we demonstrate distinct linear and quadratic associations between global signal topography and age for the first time.

referenced_paper_title.value: The NKI-Rockland sample: a model for accelerating the pace of discovery science in psychiatry
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is referenced in the paper, indicating its source and earlier description.
referenced_paper_title.quote: All fMRI data was sourced from the Nathan Kline Institute Enhanced Rockland Sample (NKI-RS) repository. This dataset has been detailed in previous work: (Nooner et al., 2012) The NKI-Rockland sample: a model for accelerating the pace of discovery science in psychiatry. Frontiers in Neuroscience, 6, 152.

name.justification: The library was used for fMRI data preprocessing.
name.quote: Data were preprocessed using FSL, AFNI, and SPM functions through DPARSF-A in DPABI (2).

referenced_paper_title.justification: FSL is a widely used library for the analysis of brain imaging data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Data were preprocessed using FSL, AFNI, and SPM functions through DPARSF-A in DPABI (2).
